newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- tone seen slightly better.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- tone seen slightly better.

text.p: U.S. municipal bonds were mostly unchanged at midday Thursday, though traders said they noticed an improved tone amid a higher Treasury market.
Fixed income markets were weaker at the start of trading, but have since drifted higher in lackluster action.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was up 12/32 at 96-4/32 to yield 6.93 percent.
"For the most part, sentiment probably is still slightly positive, but not as positive as it has been," one muni trader said.
New issues this week moved well, but traders said supply continues to be too low to get activity levels back to normal.
"We need some paper to give the market some blood," a second trader said. He said a few bid-wanted lists generated by bond funds were circulating Thursday, but nothing substantial.
The Blue List of secondary market offerings rose slightly Thursday to $964 million, but the level is still well below average.
Secondary quotes were flat, with bids on Chicago Board of Education AMBAC 5-3/4s of 2020 unchanged at 5.91 percent. Port of Seattle FGIC 5-1/2s of 2022 were down one basis point to 5.81 percent.

In debt futures, the June municipal contract reversed early losses, and were up 7/32 at 115-1/32. June T-bonds were 9/32 higher at 109-19/32. The MOB spread narrowed to 174 ticks from 176 ticks at the close Wednesday.
In follow through action from Wednesday, J.P. Morgan Securities said it had a $14.6 million balance on Tennessee's $173 million bond deal.
